root.pub-comments: See Rodrigues, this volume; see also Rogrigues 1999:199

child.pub-comments: Ethnologue lists as distinct languages Urumi and Karo (Itogapúk, Itogapuc, Ntogapig, Ntogapid, Ramarama, Itanga, Arara-Karo, Uruku, Arára do Jiparaná, Arára), saying it has a dialect “Karo.” Speakers: 92
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. The classification of South American languages. In Lyle Campbell & Verónica Grondona (eds.), South America. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. , Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 74-75. London, New York: Routledge.

child.pub-comments: Ethnologue considers Itogapuk an alternative name for Karo. Speakers: 95

child.pub-comments: Rodrigues (1999:109) lists Cinta-Larga and Zoro as independent languages in the Mondé branch; Ethnologue also has Cinta Larga as distinct Mondé language; it lists Gavião do Jiparaná (Gavião do Rondônia, Digüt, Ikõro) as a distinct language (with dialects: Gavião, Zoró (Panginey, Cabeça Seca), said to be “partially intelligible with Suruí.” Speakers: 12

child.pub-comments: Akuntsú may be a dialect of Mekens or a distinct language closely related to Mekens. Campbell signifies that Amniape is extinct, but none of the other alternate names and it is unclear from the source why he does so.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. The classification of South American languages. In Lyle Campbell & Verónica Grondona (eds.), South America. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. , Kaufman, Terrence. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 74-75. London, New York: Routledge.
